Limit the info you give out about yourself. Your credit card, mail, phone, wallet and online accounts can all be sources of personal information.

DYK that your landlord is legally required to handle and pay for emergency repairs?

Whether it’s a broken pipe flooding your apartment or a supplied fridge that isn’t cooling, it’s up to your landlord to get it fixed. If your health or safety is in danger until the repairs can be made, get in touch with your landlord or emergency contact right away.

Learn more about emergency repairs and your rights as a tenant: http://ow.ly/BUra30fGVEC

Got an email warning you that your account will be frozen within 24 hours? Don’t take the bait! It could be a cyber threat. 

Over 16 million phishing emails make it through spam filters every day. Nearly half of those emails are opened, and over 800,000 links are clicked. In fact, 7% of Canadians have replied to spoof or phishing mail unknowingly. Find out how to recognize a scam: http://ow.ly/LWLg30fPDdi

“Who is your celebrity soulmate?”

Taking such polls on your favourite social networking sites can be fun, but many turn out to be money-making schemes.

Are you self-employed and looking to save for retirement without paying high administrative costs? 

A Pooled Registered Pension Plan (PRPP) is a retirement savings option that allows you to benefit from lower administration costs that result from participating in a large, pooled pension plan. Its members can benefit from greater flexibility in managing their savings and meeting their retirement goals.

Learn more about PRPPs: http://ow.ly/YMrS30fGURu

Looking to save? Many financial transactions involve convenience fees. You may not think about them in the moment, but they can add up.

For example, many ATMs charge a fee to take out cash. Planning ahead and grabbing some cash where you won’t be charged – like from your bank’s local branch – can add up to big savings over a year! 

More tips about ATMs and withdrawing money: http://ow.ly/dUHm30fPDSG

If you plan to treat yourself this Halloween, make sure you aren’t tricked in the process!

Online shopping is a fun and easy way to find that perfect costume. However, if a last-minute deal looks too good to be true, it probably is! Scammers capitalize on holiday-focused shopping by promoting luxury products, only to send disappointing rip-offs with no way for you to process a refund.

If you have a bad experience when you order something online, contact your provincial or territorial consumer affairs office: http://ow.ly/UHmK30fZUwc
